tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"This is a maschil that Asaph wrote." See how "a psalm of Asaph" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:050:001|50:1]].
This may refer to a style of music. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:032:001|32:1]].
"me as I teach you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The word "mouth" is a metonym for the person who speaks them. AT: "my words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"open my mouth and tell parables" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"tell." See how "pours out" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:019:001|19:2]].
If your language has a word for sayings that are purposely difficult to understand, you might use it here.
Verse 3 continues the sentence begun in verse 2.

tn.ref: We will not keep them from their descendants
tn.text: "We will certainly tell our descendants about them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
"the things we praise Yahweh for"
"Yahweh established"
Other possible meanings are "testimonies" or "laws."
The writer speaks of the "children" of [[:en:bible:notes:psa:078:005|78:5-6]].
This is possibly a metaphor for not keeping the covenant (verse 10), but it is best to translate literally.
"The Ephraimite soldiers"
The soldiers probably also had arrows. AT: "had bows and arrows for weapons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to the area around the city of Zoan, which was in Egypt. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"God split"

tn.ref: enough to fill the depths of the sea
tn.text: This is probably hyperbole. AT: "more water than they could possibly drink" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
small rivers
They wanted God to prove that he could do what he said he would do before they would believe him.
"with their whole hearts"
"so they could eat as much as they desired"
the Israelites spoke

tn.ref: Can God really lay out a table for us in the wilderness?
tn.text: This can be translated as a statement. AT: "We do not believe that God can really lay out a table for us in the wilderness!" or "God, prove to us that you can really lay out a table for us in the wilderness!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"provide us with food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
much water came out quickly

tn.ref: But can he give bread also? Will he provide meat for his people?
tn.text: The people are laughing at God to insult him with these questions. AT: "But we will not believe that he can give us bread also or provide meat for his people until we see him do it." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
food from plants or food from animals. Though this is a merism for all kinds of food, it is best to translate it literally if possible. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"because he was angry, he attacked Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: did not trust in his salvation
tn.text: "did not trust him to save them"
Asaph speaks of the skies as if they were a person who could hear and obey God's commands. AT: "he spoke to the sky" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Possible meanings are 1) "sky" or 2) "clouds."

tn.ref: opened the doors of the sky
tn.text: Asaph speaks of the sky as if it were a storeroom with doors. AT: "opened the sky as if it were a storeroom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He rained down manna for them to eat, and gave them the grain from heaven
tn.text: These two lines speak of the same event.
"He caused manna to fall from the sky like rain"
This speaks of the manna. "the same kind of food that angels eat."
"a large amount of food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"God caused"

tn.ref: He rained down meat on them like dust
tn.text: "He caused meat to fall from the sky like rain, and there was so much of it that it covered the ground like dust" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
birds

tn.ref: like dust ... as numerous as the sands of the sea
tn.text: There were more birds than anyone could count. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"strongly desired"
while the food was still in their mouths ([[:en:bible:notes:psa:078:029|78:31]])
"God was angry and attacked them." See how "his anger attacked Israel" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:078:021|78:21]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"killed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: did not believe his wonderful deeds
tn.text: The word "deeds" is a metonym for God, who did the deeds. What they did not believe can be stated clearly. AT: "did not believe that he would take care of them even though he had done such wonderful deeds" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The writer continues telling of what God did to the Israelites.
"killed them while they were still young" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: their years were filled with terror
tn.text: Asaph speaks of years as if they were containers. AT: "year after year they were afraid all the time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
to ask him what they needed to do so he would protect them (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: afflicted them, they would ... they would return and look
tn.text: These are different people from those whose days God "cut short." When some of them died, others would "start to seek" God.
"would repent" or "would be truly sorry for their sins"
"urgently" or "as best they could"
The tells of what the Israelites did.
"remember." See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:020:003|20:3]].

The writer speaks about God as if he were a hill or mountain where people could go to be safe from their enemies. AT: "God was the one who protected them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"the one who rescued them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"tell him he was wonderful when they did not believe it"
The word "mouths" is a metonym for the words they spoke using their mouths. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: their hearts were not firmly fixed on him
tn.text: "they did not trust him" or "they were not loyal to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"forgave them even though they had done evil deeds"

Asaph speaks of God's anger as if it were an angry person whom God held onto to keep him from attacking the one who had made him angry. AT: "did not punish them even though he was angry with them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: did not stir up all his wrath
tn.text: Asaph speaks of God's wrath as if it were a sleeping person whom God allowed to sleep and did not awaken. AT: "did not allow himself to become fully angry with them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"remembered." See how "call to mind" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:020:003|20:3]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The word "flesh," which is weak and then dies, is a metonym for human weakness and death. AT: "the Israelites were weak and would someday die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"places where nothing grows"
They wanted God to prove that he could do what he said he would do before they would believe him. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:078:017|78:18]].
The writer speaks of how God had rescued the Israelites.
a city in Egypt (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The writer describes what God did.
so many flies that it looked like a cloud
The flies made the Egyptians as almost as unhappy as they would have if they had eaten the Egyptians. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: gave their crops to the grasshopper and their labor to the locust
tn.text: "allowed the grasshoppers to eat all their crops and allowed the locusts to eat everything they had worked hard to produce"
"went everywhere in"
a plant-eating insect with long legs used for jumping

tn.ref: He gave their crops to the grasshopper
tn.text: Asaph speaks of the crops as a gift that God gave to the grasshoppers. AT: "He allowed the grasshopper to eat their crops" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

"he gave their labor to the locust." Asaph speaks of the people's labor as if it were a gift that God gave to the grasshoppers. The word "labor" is a metonym for the crops that their labor had produced. AT: "he allowed the locusts to eat the crops they had worked so hard to produce" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The writer continues to describe what God did to the Egyptians.
a tree that gives fruit
lightning that makes loud thunder
"He brought hail" or "He caused hail to fall" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: The fierceness of his anger lashed out against them
tn.text: Asaph speaks of God's fierceness as if it were a person who could attack another person. AT: "He was angry with them, so he suddenly and fiercely attacked them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"His fierce anger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"attacked them when they were not expecting anything to happen"

tn.ref: He sent wrath, fury, and trouble like agents who bring disaster
tn.text: Asaph speaks of wrath, fury, and trouble as though they are people God can send to do his work for him. AT: "He was so angry that he wanted to harm the Egyptians, so he made trouble for them and brought them to disaster" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
anger that makes someone want to harm others
The writer continues to describe what God did to the Egyptians.

tn.ref: He leveled a path for his anger
tn.text: The psalmist speaks of anger as if it were a person who could walk Yahweh getting ready to punish the people as if he were making a smooth road for a person to walk on. AT: "He was so angry that he did everything he could to harm them" or "It was as if his anger was an army and he made a smooth road for it to march on" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: he did not spare them from death
tn.text: "he did not keep the Egyptians from dying" or "he did not permit the Egyptians to live"

tn.ref: gave them over to the plague
tn.text: Asaph speaks of the plague as if it were a person who was going to harm the Egyptians. AT: "he made them all very ill with the plague" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"their best and most important males" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"among the families of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The writer continues to describe what God did for the people of Israel.
The writer speaks about the Israelites as if they were sheep. This means God cared for and protected the people like a shepherd does his sheep. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"completely covered"
The writer continues to describe what God did for the people of Israel.
The words "right hand" are a metonym for power. AT: "he won for himself using his own power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Possible meanings are 1) God assigned the Israelites their inheritance in the land in which the other nations had once lived or 2) God assigned to the nations he had driven out an inheritance somewhere else. "gave them land that would always be theirs"

Possible meanings are 1) he settled Israel in their own tents in the land or 2) he settled Israel in the tents from which he had driven the other nations. Most of these "tents" were actually houses, both when the other nations lived in them and when the Israelites lived in them. AT: "in their homes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The writer continues to describe what God did for the people of Israel.

These words mean almost the same thing. The writer uses them both to emphasize that the Israelites did not believe that God would either provide for them or punish evil as he had said he would. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
They wanted God to prove that he could do what he said he would do before they would believe him. See how you translated this idea in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:078:017|78:18]].
"refused to obey"
These words mean almost the same thing. The writer uses them both to emphasize that the Israelites did not do for God what they had said they would do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
The writer continues to describe what God did for the people of Israel.

tn.ref: made him angry with their high places and provoked him to jealous anger with their idols
tn.text: These two phrases are in parallel and have similar meanings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
The writer continues to describe what God did for the people of Israel.

tn.ref: He allowed his strength to be captured and gave his glory into the enemy's hand
tn.text: Asaph speaks of God's strength and glory as if they were physical objects that people could capture and hold. The words "strength" and "glory" are probably mentonyms for the ark of the covenant. The word "hand" is a metonym for the enemy's power. This can be stated in active form. AT: "He allowed his enemies to capture the glorious ark of his covenant; he simply gave it to them so they could do whatever they wanted with it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The writer continues to describe what God did for the people of Israel.

tn.ref: He handed his people over to the sword
tn.text: Asaph speaks of God's people as if they were a small object God would give as a gift, and of the sword, a metonym for death in war, as if it were a person who could receive a gift. AT: "He allowed people to kill all his people in war" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: he was angry with his heritage
tn.text: "he was angry with the people he had said would be his forever"

Possible meanings are 1) "The enemy used fire to kill all their young men" or 2) "Their young men died quickly in battle like a fire burns dry grass." Do not communicate that these people used guns. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
To "devour" is to eat everything very quickly.
the celebration when people marry
"The enemies killed many Israelite priests using swords" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Possible meanings are 1) someone forced the widows not to weep or 2) so many priests died that there was no time for proper funerals.
women whose husbands have died

tn.ref: the Lord awakened as one from sleep
tn.text: "it was as if the Lord awoke from sleeping" (see UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: like a warrior who shouts because of wine
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) like a warrior who had drunk too much wine and has become angry because he was awakened and so wants to fight or 2) like a warrior who drank much wine but is now able to think and fight well because he has slept.
The writer continues to describe what God did for the people of Israel.
"descendants of Joseph" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Ephraim was Joseph's son.
Mount Zion was in the land where the tribe of Judah lived.
"high, like the heavens" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"firm and strong, like the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
The writer continues to describe what God did
"from where he was working in the sheepfolds" [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]]
spaces with walls around them where sheep are kept safe

tn.ref: to be shepherd of Jacob, his people, and of Israel, his heritage
tn.text: The word "shepherd" is a metaphor for one who leads and protects other people. AT: "to lead and protect the descendants of Jacob, his people, and of Israel, his heritage" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"the ones he had chosen to be his forever" See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:078:062|78:62]].
The word "shepherded" is a metaphor for leading and protecting. AT: "David led them and protected them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
